blocks.value: St. Agnes was a beautiful young Roman girl who lived in the early 4th century. At the age of 12 or 13, she consecrated her virginity to God and refused to marry. According to tradition, many young men wanted to marry her, but she refused them all, saying she was already promised to Christ.

One rejected suitor reported her to the authorities as a Christian. Agnes was subjected to various tortures and humiliations but remained steadfast in her faith. She was eventually martyred, either by being stabbed in the throat or beheaded. St. Agnes is one of the most celebrated virgin martyrs of the early Church. She is the patron saint of young girls, chastity, and gardeners.
